A lot of twists and deaths. I feel like:
I just wanted to add my two cents since there are so many negative reviews. 

Episode 7 sets the new stage for a new trilogy for primarily a new audience as well as long-time fans alike. That's why it plays out like a "Greatest Hits" rather than its own film. It's vanilla\, but a nice nostalgic romp.

The Last Jedi\, is the new Star Wars\, folks. Rian Johnson has swung for the fences and created something new\, bold\, and absolutely entrancing. Sure\, it doesn't all work\, the Finn/Rose stuff is absolute filler and a distraction from the Kylo/Rey/Luke story that is some of the best storytelling in the history of the franchise.

This movie is all about eradicating the past to build your own future. And that stretches into the story itself and not just the direction Star Wars is going. What you know is over. This is Star Wars. Most people that jump on in the audience comments on RT are a vocal minority.  And is not representative at all of the general movie-going audience. That's why a turd burger like "Transformers: Revenge of the Fallen" can somehow muster 57% rating on RT from audience reviewers. Movies\, like all forms of entertainment\, are subjective. 

If you haven't seen this movie yet\, but you dig Star Wars. Go. If you have never even seen a Star Wars movie\, but are interested in checking out The Last Jedi: Go. You can legitimately watch this film and enjoy without knowing a Deathstar from a Death Trooper. 

Rian Johnson has created a new\, bold world for Star Wars full of emotionally-driven characters full of depth. He has GREATLY expanded the Star Wars mythos.  And\, apparently\, he has also created food for trolls and people who are scared of change. I cannot wait to see what he has in store for his very own trilogy.
